guide.introduction: I wanted to be able to charge my cell phone, MP3 player, and other USB devices while not having plug-in power available. This hand-crank generator, originally designed by Ben Heck, ended up working the best.
guide.introduction_rendered:
I wanted to be able to charge my cell phone, MP3 player, and other USB devices while not having plug-in power available. This hand-crank generator, originally designed by Ben Heck, ended up working the best.

Relevant parts
  • hand crank flashlight
Tools
  • #0 or #00 Philips Screwdriver
  • 10 Ohm, 1/8 Watt resistor
  • Hot Glue gun & hot glue
  • Multimeter or Continuity Tester
  • Soldering iron
  • USB A/B cable
  • Wire stripper/crimper
  • Zener diode, 5.1V, 1N4733A

lines.text: I'm taking a trip to China soon, and last summer we spent a week without power due to downed trees all over the state. Let's just say it was a rough week. So I wanted to find a way to charge my USB stuff without using those battery packs. Originally I was thinking of making an Altoids can AA battery charger, until I stumbled upon Ben Heck's video on YouTube.
lines.text_raw: I'm taking a trip to China soon, and last summer we spent a week without power due to downed trees all over the state. Let's just say it was a rough week. lines.text: First - RESEARCH. I needed to look up the pin specifications of a USB cord and find a USB extension cord. I needed the female end as well as the male end for testing.
lines.text_raw: First - RESEARCH. I needed to look up the pin specifications of a USB cord and find a USB extension cord. I needed the female end as well as the male end for testing.

lines.text: Second - I hit up Walmart and Harbor Freight for cheap hand-crank flashlights. I ended up getting 3 different lights. I got a Gordon crank light ($8), a Gordon LED Dynamo flashlight ($8 for a 2-pack), and an Energizer hand-crank flashlight ($10).

lines.text: USB Pins - A quick Google search and you can find all this info, but basically on a regular USB-A cable you need the red and black wires.

lines.text: Next was a trip to YouTube and to RadioShack. Ben Heck from Element14.com has a video on this exact project.

lines.text: At RadioShack you will need to pick up a 10-ohm resistor as well as a 5V zener diode.
lines.text_raw: At RadioShack you will need to pick up a 10-ohm resistor as well as a 5V zener diode.

lines.text: I found that the small hand-crank LED light from Harbor Freight worked the best due to the fact that it was the only one with a rectifier. Solder your resistor and diode as seen in the picture (borrowed from Ben's YouTube channel).

lines.text: SIDE NOTE - You can actually remove all of the other components (3.6v battery, misc. resistors) from the PCB. You only need the rectifier.
lines.text_raw: SIDE NOTE - You can actually remove all of the other components (3.6v battery, misc. resistors) from the PCB. You only need the rectifier.

lines.text: Finally, solder the red and black leads to the rectifier and the resistor as shown in the picture in the previous step. Plug in your phone/iPod/whatever and crank your heart out.

lines.text: Use your multimeter to make sure the diode is only putting out 5V (or thereabouts). If the voltage is higher, you could damage your device.
